channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Can you pass the new, more challenging U.S. citizenship test?
item.description: The test changes come after the Trump administration signaled it will increase scrutiny on citizenship applications and threatened to revoke some Americans’ citizenship. The Washington Post set 10 questions to represent the 2025 civics test.

item.title: Trump administration will allow controversial road through Alaskan refuge
item.description: The deal allows a road to cut through the Izembek National Wildlife Refuge, a pristine stretch of coastal wildlands. Interior Secretary Doug Burgum also announced the reopening of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas development.

item.title: The White House annex has been completely demolished to make way for Trump’s $300 million ballroom
item.description: The little that remained just after lunchtime included a small section of the East Colonnade, a corridor that previously connected the East Wing to the main White House. Also visible: dump trucks with sandy-colored debris.

item.title: Senate blocks bills to pay federal workers during shutdown as it stretches into a fourth week, with no end in sight
item.description: Lawmakers acted mostly along partisan lines.

item.title: Trump pardons founder of crypto exchange Binance, Changpeng Zhao, who pleaded guilty to enabling money laundering in 2023
item.description: Zhao agreed to step down as chief executive of Binance as part of a plea deal. The company also agreed to pay a $4.3 billion fine.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: He’d be a great dad. Is it wrong to marry him just for that?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: He’d be a great dad. Is it wrong to marry him just for that?

item.title: Support for Virginia Democratic attorney general nominee has tumbled since text message scandal, Post-Schar School poll finds
item.description: Likely voters have not transferred much support to Jay Jones’s opponent — Republican incumbent Jason S. Miyares — and the race is a tie, according to a Washington Post-Schar School poll. The scandal has not affected the contest for governor, where Democrat Abigail Spanberger holds a 12-point lead over Republican Winsome Earle-Sears.

item.title: NBA’s Portland Trail Blazers head coach and Miami Heat player arrested in sports gambling probe
item.description: FBI agents reportedly arrested Trail Blazers coach Chauncey Billups, a Hall of Famer who played 17 seasons in the league, and the Heat’s Terry Rozier, a former first-round draft pick. Former NBA player Damon Jones was also taken into custody, according to a person familiar with the situation.

item.title: Stealing jewels in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: U.S. Anglican Church archbishop accused of sexual misconduct, abuse of power
item.description: An attempted kiss, cash payments and other allegations roil the Anglican Church in North America.

item.title: Trump’s ballroom. Boat strikes. Shutdown. Nuclear submarines. Citizenship test. mRNA vaccines. Brain surgery. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: U.S. imposes sanctions on Russian oil companies after strikes on Ukraine kill 7
item.description: The move against two of Russia’s largest oil companies, Rosneft and Lukoil, reflects the Trump administration’s waning patience with Russian President Vladimir Putin. The Treasury Department cited Putin’s alleged “lack of serious commitment to a peace process to end the war in Ukraine” in its announcement of the measures.

item.title: Trump’s teardown of the East Wing moves full steam ahead as shocked preservationists fear their hands are tied
item.description: The president said Wednesday that the project would cost $300 million, up from his initial claim of $200 million, as he defended the decision to demolish the East Wing of the White House to build his long-desired ballroom.

item.title: University of Virginia agrees to follow Trump administration’s guidance barring discrimination in deal to pause investigations
item.description: The deal could be the first such agreement between any public university and the White House, as President Donald Trump seeks to remake higher education. His administration contends that many universities have violated civil rights laws by embracing diversity, equity and inclusion programs or failing to adequately protect Jewish students.

item.title: U.S. kills 2 people in strike on alleged drug boat in Pacific, expanding Trump’s counternarcotics campaign beyond Caribbean
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced the strike but declined to identify the victims or offer evidence verifying that they were hauling narcotics. Previous strikes were launched exclusively in the Caribbean Sea targeting what President Donald Trump contends are criminal organizations linked to Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Pentagon announces its new right-wing press corps after mass walkout over Defense Department’s reporting restrictions
item.description: A new crop of conservative media and influencers — including the Gateway Pundit, The Post Millennial, Human Events and the National Pulse — signed an agreement with the Defense Department.

item.title: I need alone time, but my husband is always home: Carolyn Hax’s readers give advice
item.description: I need alone time, but my husband is always home: Carolyn Hax’s readers give advice

item.title: A ‘rogue’ in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Americans see insurance costs surge as health subsidy fight fuels shutdown
item.description: Many states have shown rising premiums ahead of open enrollment for Affordable Care Act plans. The government shutdown is driven by Democratic demands to extend subsidies for this insurance.

item.title: East Wing demolition. Vladimir Putin. Shutdown impact. Trump nominee. AI warnings. CNN’s future. Gen Z at work. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump’s controversial nominee to lead the Office of Special Counsel withdraws from confirmation hearing
item.description: Paul Ingrassia withdrew after at least five GOP senators said they opposed him, in the wake of reports that he sent racist and inflammatory texts.

item.title: Eating meat is worse for the planet in some cities than in others. Look up yours.
item.description: For the first time, researchers calculated the planet-warming pollution emitted from raising the beef, pork and chicken Americans eat for every town and city in the country.

item.title: Correction: Trump administration seeks to move special education to a different agency as it works to close the Education Dept.
item.description: An earlier alert said the government was seeking to move special education programs to the Department of Health and Human Services. Education officials have floated the idea of moving special education to HHS, but the official who confirmed Tuesday that a move was being explored said there are multiple agencies involved in the discussions.

item.title: New photo shows much of the White House East Wing torn down as demolition continues for Trump’s ballroom
item.description: More of the structure was torn down Tuesday to make way for President Donald Trump’s planned ballroom, despite complaints about the project’s lack of transparency.

item.title: Trump administration seeks to move special education to HHS as it works to close the Education Department
item.description: The move comes on the heels of the agency’s decision this month to lay off the vast majority of employees working on special education services and months after Education Secretary Linda McMahon talked about moving the program to the Department of Health and Human Services.

item.title: The administration’s push to overhaul the U.S. refugee program seeks 7,000 White South Africans — and virtually no one else
item.description: If the Trump administration succeeds, almost all people admitted to the United States as refugees could be Afrikaners, a group not traditionally eligible for the program. The remainder may be chosen because of their ability to speak English or their views on “free speech,” people familiar with the matter said.

item.title: Trump-Putin meeting postponed after Russia’s top diplomat signaled a wide chasm between U.S. and Kremlin on Ukraine
item.description: The Trump administration said there are “no plans” for President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin to meet in Hungary in the immediate future. The decision came after Russia’s foreign minister said Trump’s call for a ceasefire contradicted the understandings he reached with Putin.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Husband wants to hide their Halloween from his devil-fearing mother
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Husband wants to hide their Halloween from his devil-fearing mother

item.title: Futures of CNN and HBO at stake as Warner Bros. Discovery announces it’s open to a full or partial sale
item.description: The media company, which previously announced a plan to split its entertainment offerings from its sports and news programming, has decided to explore sale opportunities after receiving multiple bids. David Ellison, whose company Skydance recently took over Paramount, has reportedly expressed interest.

item.title: North Carolina lawmakers vote to add GOP House seat, in win for Trump ahead of 2026 midterms
item.description: Republican state senators heeded President Donald Trump’s request to help protect the party’s narrow majority in next year’s elections. The state House is expected to sign off on the measure later this week. Gov. Josh Stein (D) does not have the power to veto it, leaving Democrats with few options but to sue.

item.title: The greatest game in baseball history in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: How Joe Rogan’s podcast with Mel Gibson led Florida to promise research into ivermectin as a cancer treatment
item.description: Ivermectin, an antiparasitic drug that gained fame as a possible covid treatment despite research showing its ineffectiveness, has taken on symbolic power in the backlash against traditional public health guidance that helped spawn the “Make America Healthy Again” movement.

item.title: East Wing demolition. Trump and Zelensky. Louvre heist. Mel Gibson. Climate ‘hoofprint.’ Good sleep. World Series. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: The Toronto Blue Jays advanced to the Fall Classic for first time since 1993, where they will take on the Los Angeles Dodgers
item.description: The Blue Jays rallied past the visiting Seattle Mariners, 4-3, in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series on Monday night.

item.title: Four surprising things that may reduce your risk of Parkinson’s
item.description: Research on Parkinson’s is revealing several risk factors related to our lifestyles and environment, and you can act on some of them.

item.title: Six of nine top colleges have rejected the Trump administration’s funding deal ahead of Monday deadline
item.description: Despite strong pressure from the White House, including a Friday call, colleges and universities are largely rejecting President Donald Trump’s offer of preferential treatment for funding in exchange for compliance with his ideological priorities. On Monday, the University of Arizona and Vanderbilt University did not accept the deal, but said they were open to more discussion.

item.title: Former FBI director James B. Comey asks judge to dismiss criminal case against him, calling it vindictive
item.description: In court filings, Comey’s attorneys accused President Donald Trump of personally instigating the case against their client. When several prosecutors refused to proceed, the attorneys wrote, Trump installed a loyalist in a key position to ensure that charges would be filed.

item.title: Two more teens charged in August attack on DOGE staffer that propelled Trump’s D.C. takeover
item.description: An 18- and a 19-year-old face charges including robbery and assault for their alleged role in the Aug. 3 attack on Edward Coristine — a 19-year-old software engineer known as “Big Balls” — and another person at a nearby gas station, U.S. Attorney for D.C. Jeanine Pirro announced Monday. Earlier this month, two 15-year-olds were sentenced to probation for their role in the incidents.

item.title: Trump can deploy National Guard in Portland, appeals court rules
item.description: A federal judge appointed by President Donald Trump had blocked him from sending federalized National Guard members to Oregon’s largest city.

item.title: Demolition of White House facade begins, contradicting Trump’s claim that addition wouldn’t interfere with current structure
item.description: Construction teams Monday demolished a portion of the East Wing, with a backhoe ripping through the structure, according to a photo shared with The Washington Post and two people who witnessed the activity. The ballroom project, long desired by President Donald Trump, is estimated to cost $250 million.

item.title: Man was driving in reverse when he plowed through child’s party in Maryland on Saturday, killing 1 and injuring 13, police say
item.description: The driver, identified Monday as 66-year-old Sunday Joseph, ran before turning himself in to authorities Sunday morning, officials said.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: He regrets not exploring his bisexuality before he married his wife
item.description: Carolyn Hax: He regrets not exploring his bisexuality before he married his wife

item.title: Officials and locals undercut Trump’s claims that boats off Venezuela are carrying deadly fentanyl to the U.S.
item.description: Records and interviews with 20 people familiar with the route or the strikes show that the targeted passage in the waters between Venezuela and Trinidad and Tobago typically carries cocaine and marijuana to other continents.

item.title: ‘Mad Mike’ in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Israeli strikes. Marco Rubio. Military exercise. Inflation. Louvre heist. Parkinson’s prevention. Rare comets. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: This Stanford scientist and Berkshire Hathaway heir is on a mission to thwart redistricting efforts in California
item.description: Charles Munger Jr. is the largest individual donor opposing the California ballot measure that would redraw the state’s congressional map to favor Democrats.

item.title: These two infectious disease experts say this is when you should get covid and flu shots
item.description: Flu season is here. The summer wave of the coronavirus has receded, but the winter uptick is likely around the corner. The Washington Post spoke to two experts about how they make their own decisions and how they talk about vaccines with friends and families.

item.title: Gen Z slang is everywhere. Test your knowledge of teen talk with this quiz.
item.description: Gen Z slang is everywhere. Do you understand it?

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: She spurned the concertmaster’s advance. Now she’s classical music’s #MeToo vigilante.
item.description: Baltimore Symphony oboist Katherine Needleman’s online shaming campaign has sidelined several musicians — and outraged others.
